title.title: The Correspondence of John Hunt and Joshua Evans

msIdentifier.institution: Friends Historical Library of Swarthmore College

projectDesc.p: The correspondence of Quaker ministers John Hunt and Joshua Evans are stored at the Friends Historical Library of Swarthmore College. With the generous support of H. David and Joyce E. Hunt, Library staff scanned and transcribed these letters in 2023 and encoded the text in TEI. The 2023 project also included researching individuals mentioned in the text to create and update records about them in the Social Networks and Archival Context website

body.head: To the preparative meetings of Friends of Upper and Lower Evesham
body.p: feeling my mind drawn in love to you all, I write. And notwithstanding we are far separated from each other, I often remember you may be with great nearness and longing desires that you may be favored to keep near to the pure fountain of life that only can preserve from the snares of death. And although we have many trials both inward & outward to pass through, yet let none be discouraged in their minds. For it is nothing new or strange being the way that all the faithful have to pass through in every age of the world, and the Lord’s power is the same as ever it was and he as attentive to the cries of his poor afflicted children as ever. Therefore let all depend upon him for help.

But dear Friends, if there is a growing easy in our minds and a giving way to those things that the light hath made manifest to us to be contrary to the Lord’s pure will, we shall lose our strength and become dead and formal. But oh, that this may never be the case with any of those that have set their faces Zionwards, but let all be faithful according to ability received in order that the Lord’s work may forward amongst us and the dear youth for whom my heart is often humbly bowed before the Lord in secret that they may be preserved on this day of great difficulty. But oh dear youth, faithfulness is the way to fruitfulness, and if you are faithful to what is your duty, you will grow strong in the
and become useful in your day. It is in great fear and deep self abasement I trust I write to you at this time but could not be easy, till I gave up thereto.

closer.salute: I now conclude in much love to you both aged and youth and remain your faithful friend and sister in the fellowship of theGreat Blessed Truth,
closer.dateline: Great Eggharbour the 23 of the 7th month 1792
